title: Livelihood Trajectories and HIV and AIDS in South West Uganda -- a longitudinal study of rural households
abstractText:
The main objective of the research is to assess the impact of HIV-infection on households over a 15 year period (1991-2006) in a rural setting in Uganda. The research will take place in south west Uganda in collaboration with the Medical Research Council/ Uganda Virus Research Institute Research Unit on AIDS in Uganda, which has been conducting research in the area since 1989. The MRC/UVRI established a General Population Cohort study (GPC) in 1989 in 15 rural villages (expanded to 25 villages in 2000). 

This project has three parts:

  1. A repeat of a 1991-2 study using in-depth interviewing and participant observation to document everyday life over a period of 12 months of the members of 27 households living in the area covered by the GPC; 
  2. A study of 120 additional households drawn from the GPC using both quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the impact of HIV infection on households from a health economics perspective with a particular focus on the lives of affected children;
  3. The examination of the wider impact of HIV infection on the household life-cycle from a life-course perspective through the secondary analysis of annual GPC census and survey information collected continuously since 1989.
impactText: Informed the work of other researchers and also provided an update for the information used by various organisations on the impact of HIV on livelihoods Healthcare,Other Societal
findingsText:
We revisited families originally visited in 1991 (visited every month for a year) to find out how lives and livelihoods had developed over the 16 years, looking particularly at the impact of HIV on people's lives.

Please see the final report and impact summary for this award. The findings fed into further research on the impact of HIV and formed the basis for a book. Healthcare,Other
